EUV lithography uses 13.5 nm radiation from a laser-produced plasma (LPP) in tin [@Banine2011]. Micron-sized tin droplets are hit by two CO₂ laser pulses: a pre-pulse shapes the droplet; a main pulse vaporizes it into a hot plasma emitting EUV radiation [@Wagner2010].

The underlying plasma physics and efficiency limits of LPP sources for microlithography represent one of the most challenging engineering achievements in modern semiconductor manufacturing [@Banine2011; @Bakshi2006].

::: {.callout-important}
#### Data & Facts
- Droplet: 20–30 μm; ~50,000 droplets/s  
- Pre-pulse ~5 kW; Main pulse 25–30 kW  
- Plasma temperature > 2.2×10⁵ °C  
- Conversion efficiency ~3–5%  
- Operates in high vacuum; hydrogen protects mirrors
:::

### Takeaway
EUV is man-made starlight: a tiny tin droplet becomes a plasma hotter than the Sun’s surface to emit 13.5 nm radiation.
:::

### Plasma Physics and Spectral Characteristics

The tin plasma emits broadband EUV radiation centered around 13.5 nm, with line-rich spectra from highly charged tin ions [@Tallents2010]. The spectral purity and conversion efficiency are critical parameters that determine the overall system performance [@Stulen1999].

```{python}
#| label: euv-spectrum
#| fig-cap: "EUV spectral emission from tin plasma showing the 13.5 nm peak"

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Generate synthetic EUV spectrum data
wavelength = np.linspace(10, 17, 1000)
# Main 13.5 nm peak with satellite lines
main_peak = 100 * np.exp(-((wavelength - 13.5)**2) / (2 * 0.3**2))
satellite1 = 30 * np.exp(-((wavelength - 12.8)**2) / (2 * 0.2**2))
satellite2 = 25 * np.exp(-((wavelength - 14.2)**2) / (2 * 0.25**2))
background = 5 + 2 * np.random.random(len(wavelength))

intensity = main_peak + satellite1 + satellite2 + background

plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.plot(wavelength, intensity, 'b-', linewidth=2, label='Tin plasma emission')
plt.axvline(x=13.5, color='r', linestyle='--', alpha=0.7, label='Target wavelength')
plt.fill_between(wavelength, intensity, alpha=0.3)
plt.xlabel('Wavelength (nm)')
plt.ylabel('Relative Intensity')
plt.title('EUV Spectral Emission from Tin Plasma')
plt.legend()
plt.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
```

### Collector Mirror System

A large collector mirror with multilayer coatings gathers and redirects EUV towards the illuminator [@Goldberg2004]. The collector design must balance:

- **Collection efficiency** — Maximizing captured EUV radiation
- **Debris mitigation** — Protecting mirror surfaces from tin contamination  
- **Thermal management** — Handling intense heat loads
- **Spectral filtering** — Selecting desired 13.5 nm radiation

Hydrogen gas helps convert tin debris into volatile hydrides (SnH₄), protecting the collector from contamination [@Banine2011].

### Advanced Droplet Generation and Timing

The droplet generation system operates with extraordinary precision [@Bakshi2006]:

```{python}
#| label: droplet-timing
#| fig-cap: "Timing diagram for EUV source operation showing critical synchronization"

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Time axis in microseconds
time = np.linspace(0, 100, 1000)

# Droplet trajectory (simplified)
droplet_pos = 50 - 0.5 * time  # Moving towards interaction zone

# Pre-pulse timing
pre_pulse = np.zeros_like(time)
pre_pulse[(time >= 20) & (time <= 25)] = 1

# Main pulse timing  
main_pulse = np.zeros_like(time)
main_pulse[(time >= 30) & (time <= 32)] = 1

# EUV emission (follows main pulse)
euv_emission = np.zeros_like(time)
euv_mask = (time >= 32) & (time <= 40)
euv_emission[euv_mask] = np.exp(-(time[euv_mask] - 32) / 3)

fig, (ax1, ax2, ax3, ax4) = plt.subplots(4, 1, figsize=(12, 8), sharex=True)

# Droplet position
ax1.plot(time, droplet_pos, 'b-', linewidth=2)
ax1.set_ylabel('Droplet Position\n(relative)')
ax1.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
ax1.set_title('EUV Source Timing Sequence')

# Pre-pulse
ax2.fill_between(time, pre_pulse, alpha=0.7, color='orange', label='Pre-pulse')
ax2.set_ylabel('Pre-pulse\nPower')
ax2.set_ylim(-0.1, 1.2)
ax2.grid(True, alpha=0.3)

# Main pulse
ax3.fill_between(time, main_pulse, alpha=0.7, color='red', label='Main pulse')
ax3.set_ylabel('Main Pulse\nPower')
ax3.set_ylim(-0.1, 1.2)
ax3.grid(True, alpha=0.3)

# EUV emission
ax4.fill_between(time, euv_emission, alpha=0.7, color='purple', label='EUV emission')
ax4.set_ylabel('EUV Intensity')
ax4.set_xlabel('Time (μs)')
ax4.grid(True, alpha=0.3)

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
```

Droplets (20–30 μm diameter) are emitted at ~50 kHz frequency. The pre-pulse laser must hit within microseconds to flatten the droplet into a pancake shape for maximum absorption; the main pulse follows to create the EUV-emitting plasma.

### Power Scaling and Efficiency Challenges

Current EUV sources achieve 3-5% conversion efficiency from laser power to useful EUV radiation [@Wagner2010]. Future high-volume manufacturing requires:

```{python}
#| label: power-scaling
#| fig-cap: "EUV source power scaling requirements for future technology nodes"

import plotly.graph_objects as go
import pandas as pd

# Power scaling data
years = [2020, 2022, 2024, 2026, 2028, 2030]
laser_power = [25, 30, 35, 45, 55, 70]  # kW
euv_power = [p * 0.04 for p in laser_power]  # 4% efficiency
throughput = [150, 170, 190, 220, 250, 300]  # WPH

fig = go.Figure()

# Laser power
fig.add_trace(go.Scatter(
    x=years, y=laser_power,
    mode='lines+markers',
    name='Laser Power (kW)',
    line=dict(color='red', width=3),
    marker=dict(size=8)
))

# EUV power (secondary axis)
fig.add_trace(go.Scatter(
    x=years, y=euv_power,
    mode='lines+markers',
    name='EUV Power (kW)',
    line=dict(color='blue', width=3),
    marker=dict(size=8),
    yaxis='y2'
))

# Throughput (secondary axis)
fig.add_trace(go.Scatter(
    x=years, y=[t/100 for t in throughput],  # Scale for visibility
    mode='lines+markers',
    name='Throughput (×100 WPH)',
    line=dict(color='green', width=3, dash='dash'),
    marker=dict(size=8),
    yaxis='y2'
))

fig.update_layout(
    title='EUV Source Power Scaling Roadmap',
    xaxis_title='Year',
    yaxis=dict(title='Laser Power (kW)', side='left'),
    yaxis2=dict(title='EUV Power (kW) / Throughput (×100 WPH)', side='right', overlaying='y'),
    width=800,
    height=500
)

fig.show()
```

Key challenges include:
- **Thermal management** of high-power laser systems
- **Debris mitigation** to protect optical components  
- **Conversion efficiency** improvements beyond current 4-5%
- **Reliability** for 24/7 manufacturing operations
